response:
Apologies for the confusion. Now I realize the source of the issue could be the nature of the `subjects.txt` data we're trying to merge. As the provided data contains just one line, it could be causing the merge operation to fail due to no matching IDs. 

Assuming we've more rows in the actual `subjects.txt` data that match with the IDs in `metRmOlWithDbgapIdHeader.txt` data, a modified version of the code is given below:

```
# Load necessary library
library(tidyverse)

# Load the data
cpg_data <- read.table("metRmOlWithDbgapIdHeader.txt", header = TRUE, row.names = 1, sep = "\t", check.names = FALSE)

# Transpose data and convert to data frame
cpg_data <- data.frame(t(cpg_data), check.names = FALSE)

# Load subject data
subjects <- read.table("subjects.txt", header = TRUE, sep = "\t", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

# Rename first column of our transposed cpg dataset
names(cpg_data)[1] <- "dbGaP_ID"

combined_data <- merge(subjects, cpg_data , by = "dbGaP_ID")

# Converting categorical vars to numerical
combined_data$sex = as.numeric(as.factor(combined_data$sex))
combined_data$Race = as.numeric(as.factor(combined_data$Race))

# Correlation function to calculate spearman correlation
correlation_spearman <- function(x){
  age_corr <- cor.test(combined_data$Age, x, method = "spearman")
  sex_corr <- cor.test(combined_data$sex, x, method = "spearman")
  race_corr<- cor.test(combined_data$Race, x, method = "spearman")
  
  p_value_compound <- c(age_corr$p.value, sex_corr$p.value, race_corr$p.value)
  
  return(p_value_compound)
}

# Apply correlation function
correlation_results <- apply(combined_data[,-c(1:5)], 2, correlation_spearman)

# Rename for clarity
colnames(correlation_results) <- c("p_age", "p_sex", "p_race")

# t() for a better view
correlation_results <- t(correlation_results)

# Filter CpGs associated only with Age not Sex or Race
results <- subset(correlation_results, (p_age < 0.05 & p_sex > 0.05 & p_race > 0.05))

# Sort and output top 20 results
top_CpGs <- head(results[order(results[, "p_age"]), ], 20)
top_CpGs
```

In this modified code script, categorical variables 'sex' and 'Race' were correctly converted to numerical data to apply spearman correlation. Then, spearman correlations were calculated for 'Age', 'sex' and 'Race' for each CpG site. Finally, CpG sites were filtered to retain only those which were correlated with 'Age' but not with 'sex' or 'Race', and top 20 CpG sites were displayed.
